prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not keeping my husband undisturbed while he works from home.
My husband switched jobs within the past year or so and new job allows him to work from home  a few days a week.  He decided to set up his office in our bedroom.  I suggested he set up in the basement where he would be guaranteed silence and very little disruption.  He prefers to work from our bedroom because the view is better.  His job is 90% conference calls so while he is up there, I have to keep kids from disturbing him which basically means the whole top floor of our house is off limits while he is on calls.  It also means I can’t shower in my bathroom, do chores, put away laundry, or even take a nap when the baby is sleeping.  I also work from home but also take on most of the house chores and dealing with kids.  Him being up there negates my ability to take a damn shower or a poop in peace when I want to.   Since we have adequate space in the basement I told him that we would never bother him while he is down there ever but I can’t promise him silence if he stays in our bedroom. He says i am the asshole for not being quiet when he’s on calls while I think he is the asshole for not setting his office up in the dang basement. Please resolve our fight for us.  Thank you!
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the person who wrote the story is in the wrong. The story is about a couple where the husband set up his office in their bedroom, leading to conflicts with the wife. The wife suggested the basement, but he chose the bedroom for the view. Now, she can't do daily tasks without disturbing him, and she's upset about it.

First, I need to understand both sides. The husband works from home part-time and prefers the bedroom because of the view. His job is mostly conference calls, so he needs a quiet environment when on calls. The wife, who also works from home and handles most chores and kids, finds it hard to do anything when he's in the bedroom because she can't guarantee silence. She told him she can't promise silence if he's in the bedroom but can if he's in the basement. He thinks she's the asshole for not being quiet, she thinks he's the asshole for not moving to the basement.

Now, to determine if the author (the wife) is in the wrong. The key points here are about boundaries and mutual respect. The husband chose to set up in the bedroom despite the wife's suggestion. The problem arises because his choice affects her ability to work and manage household tasks. The wife is trying to set boundaries by saying she can't promise silence in the bedroom. Is that fair?

The husband's preference for the bedroom might be valid, but it's creating a conflict. The wife is handling most of the housework and childcare, which is a lot. By choosing the bedroom, he's limiting her space. The suggestion to use the basement (which has adequate space) was a reasonable compromise, but he declined. Now the wife is asserting her need for space and quiet when possible. Since the husband's choice is causing the problem, the wife isn't wrong for standing up for her needs. She's trying to balance both their work and household responsibilities. The husband might need to consider moving to the basement to respect her space. So the answer would be B, the author is not in the wrong.
